title: 104_s1123
content:
The Act is titled the "Prohibition of Cigarette Vending Machines Accessible to Minors in Federal Buildings and Lands Act." It includes findings related to the issue. The Congress finds that cigarette smoking and the use of tobacco products are major health hazards causing over 420,000 deaths annually, with significant costs to the United States in healthcare expenses. Tobacco products contain harmful additives and nicotine, making them addictive and poisonous. Despite state laws prohibiting sales to minors, enforcement has been ineffective. The use of tobacco products among minors in the United States remains poorly regulated, with little progress made in reducing teenage smoking rates. Most smokers start before the age of 18, and a significant number of cigarettes are illegally sold to minors annually. Tobacco use is linked to illicit drug use, and the Federal Government plays a crucial role in discouraging tobacco use among minors. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, "Federal agency" refers to Executive agencies and specified entities, "Federal building" includes structures owned by the United States or a Federal agency, "minor" is an individual under 18 years, and "tobacco product" includes cigarettes and cigars. The term "tobacco product" includes cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, pipe tobacco, smokeless tobacco, snuff, and chewing tobacco. SEC. 4. TOBACCO PRODUCTS VENDING MACHINE AND FREE SAMPLE BAN IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. The Administrator of General Services and Federal agency heads must prohibit the sale of tobacco products in vending machines and the distribution of free samples in or around Federal buildings. Exceptions can be made for areas that also prohibit minors. The sale of tobacco products in vending machines and distribution of free samples in or around Federal buildings must be prohibited by the Administrator of General Services for buildings under their jurisdiction, or by the head of a Federal agency for buildings under their jurisdiction. SEC. 5. COMPLIANCE REPORT.

Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Administrator of General Services and agency heads must submit a report to Congress confirming compliance with the Act and listing the locations of tobacco vending machines in Federal buildings under their administration.

SEC. 6. APPLICATION TO THE UNITED STATES CAPITOL AND GROUNDS. The Senate and House Committees, in consultation with the Architect of the Capitol, must create regulations within 45 days of the Act's enactment to ban tobacco sales in vending machines and free samples in the Capitol Buildings. Exceptions can be made in areas that also prohibit minors. The term "Capitol Buildings" is defined as in a specific Act. The United States Capitol Grounds are regulated under the Act approved on July 31, 1946 (40 U.S.C. 193m(1)). SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit the authority of the Administrator of General Services or agency heads to restrict tobacco use in or around Federal buildings, except as provided in section 4(a).
